12.88.text: When we use the word "architect" or "designer,"

16.05.text: what we usually mean is a professional,

21.32.text: and we tend to assume that it's those professionals

24.25.text: who are going to be the ones to help us solve

26.23.text: the really big, systemic design challenges that we face

28.79.text: like climate change, urbanization and social inequality.

32.63.text: That's our kind of working presumption.

35.72.text: And I think it's wrong, actually.

38.72.text: In 2008, I was just about to graduate from architecture school

41.97.text: after several years, and go out and get a job,

47.57.text: The economy ran out of jobs.

49.82.text: And a couple of things struck me about this.

52.28.text: One, don't listen to career advisers.

56.01.text: And two, actually this is a fascinating paradox for architecture,

60.66.text: which is that, as a society, we've never needed design thinking more,

64.93.text: and yet architecture was literally becoming unemployed.

68.89.text: It strikes me that we talk very deeply about design,

72.44.text: but actually there's an economics behind architecture

74.56.text: that we don't talk about, and I think we need to.

77.02.text: And a good place to start is your own paycheck.

80.66.text: So, as a bottom-of-the-rung architecture graduate,

83.10.text: I might expect to earn about 24,000 pounds.

89.69.text: Now in terms of the whole world's population,

91.39.text: that already puts me in the top 1.95 richest people,

96.28.text: which raises the question of, who is it I'm working for?

102.75.text: actually almost everything that we call architecture today

105.63.text: is actually the business of designing

107.92.text: for about the richest one percent of the world's population,

113.08.text: The reason why we forgot that

114.82.text: is because the times in history when architecture

116.93.text: did the most to transform society were those times

119.85.text: when, actually, the one percent would build

122.51.text: on behalf of the 99 percent, for various different reasons,

125.54.text: whether that was through philanthropy in the 19th century,

130.43.text: the welfare state, and most recently, of course,

133.47.text: through this inflated real estate bubble.

137.08.text: And all of those booms, in their own various ways,

142.31.text: and we're back in this situation

144.60.text: where the smartest designers and architects in the world

149.51.text: are only really able to work for one percent of the population.

153.29.text: Now it's not just that that's bad for democracy,

155.40.text: though I think it probably is,

157.24.text: it's actually not a very clever business strategy, actually.

160.34.text: I think the challenge facing the next generation of architects

163.20.text: is, how are we going to turn our client

165.24.text: from the one percent to the 100 percent?

168.86.text: And I want to offer three slightly counterintuitive ideas

172.43.text: for how it might be done.

174.28.text: The first is, I think we need to question this idea

177.66.text: that architecture is about making buildings.

179.95.text: Actually, a building is about the most expensive solution

182.69.text: you can think of to almost any given problem.

185.71.text: And fundamentally, design should be much, much more interested

188.24.text: in solving problems and creating new conditions.

192.49.text: The office was working with a school,

194.09.text: and they had an old Victorian school building.

196.51.text: And they said to the architects, "Look,

199.25.text: our corridors are an absolute nightmare.

201.20.text: They're far too small. They get congested between classes.

203.56.text: There's bullying. We can't control them.

205.95.text: So what we want you to do is re-plan our entire building,

208.79.text: and we know it's going to cost several million pounds,

210.98.text: but we're reconciled to the fact."

212.89.text: And the team thought about this, and they went away,

215.60.text: and they said, "Actually, don't do that.

217.61.text: Instead, get rid of the school bell.

220.39.text: And instead of having one school bell that goes off once,

223.22.text: have several smaller school bells that go off

225.48.text: in different places and different times,

227.73.text: distribute the traffic through the corridors."

231.39.text: but instead of spending several million pounds,

236.34.text: Now, it looks like you're doing yourself out of a job,

239.14.text: but you're not. You're actually making yourself more useful.

241.71.text: Architects are actually really, really good

243.18.text: at this kind of resourceful, strategic thinking.

245.52.text: And the problem is that, like a lot of design professions,

247.48.text: we got fixated on the idea of providing

249.67.text: a particular kind of consumer product,

251.95.text: and I don't think that needs to be the case anymore.

254.42.text: The second idea worth questioning is this 20th-century thing

258.62.text: that mass architecture is about big --

264.47.text: Actually, we've got ourselves locked into this

266.56.text: Industrial Era mindset which says that

268.97.text: the only people who can make cities are large organizations

272.45.text: or corporations who build on our behalf,

276.78.text: in single, monolithic projects, and of course,

282.43.text: So what you end up with are single, monolithic neighborhoods

285.46.text: based on this kind of one-size-fits-all model.

289.14.text: And a lot of people can't even afford them.

291.66.text: But what if, actually, it's possible now for cities

294.62.text: to be made not just by the few with a lot

297.39.text: but also by the many with a bit?

300.58.text: And when they do, they bring with them

301.88.text: a completely different set of values about the place that they want to live.

305.22.text: And it raises really interesting questions about,

307.32.text: how will we plan cities? How will finance development?

310.60.text: How will we sell design services?

312.26.text: What would it mean for democratic societies

314.50.text: to offer their citizens a right to build?

316.90.text: And in a way it should be kind of obvious, right,

319.18.text: that in the 21st century, maybe cities can be developed by citizens.

324.65.text: And thirdly, we need to remember that,

327.82.text: from a strictly economic point of view,

330.17.text: design shares a category with sex and care of the elderly --

339.50.text: Most of the work takes place outside of the monetary economy

342.97.text: in what's called the social economy or the core economy,

345.03.text: which is people doing it for themselves.

347.42.text: And the problem is that, up until now,

350.67.text: it was the monetary economy which had

352.47.text: all the infrastructure and all the tools.

354.63.text: So the challenge we face is, how are we going

356.45.text: to build the tools, the infrastructure and the institutions

361.42.text: And that began with open-source software.

364.15.text: And over the last few years, it's been moving

366.52.text: into the physical world with open-source hardware,

370.55.text: that anyone can download and make for themselves.

374.59.text: And that's where 3D printing gets really, really interesting.

377.83.text: Right? When suddenly you had a 3D printer

381.37.text: that was open-source, the parts for which

382.92.text: could be made on another 3D printer.

385.21.text: Or the same idea here, which is for a CNC machine,

388.27.text: which is like a large printer that can cut sheets of plywood.

392.76.text: What these technologies are doing is radically

395.58.text: lowering the thresholds of time and cost and skill.

400.24.text: if you want something to be affordable it's got to be one-size-fits-all.

409.29.text: We're moving into this future where the factory is everywhere,

414.61.text: that the design team is everyone.

417.90.text: That really is an industrial revolution.

420.42.text: And when we think that the major ideological conflicts

423.64.text: that we inherited were all based around this question

425.66.text: of who should control the means of production,

427.57.text: and these technologies are coming back with a solution:

430.30.text: actually, maybe no one. All of us.

439.06.text: So about a year and a half ago,

441.58.text: we started working on a project called WikiHouse,

443.48.text: and WikiHouse is an open-source construction system.

446.75.text: And the idea is to make it possible for anyone

449.55.text: to go online, access a freely shared library

451.94.text: of 3D models which they can download and adapt in,

456.40.text: at the moment, SketchUp, because it's free, and it's easy to use,

459.79.text: and almost at the click of a switch

462.35.text: they can generate a set of cutting files

466.87.text: to print out the parts from a house using a CNC machine

470.06.text: and a standard sheet material like plywood.

473.27.text: And the parts are all numbered,

476.39.text: and basically what you end up with is a really big IKEA kit.

482.84.text: And it goes together without any bolts.

485.11.text: It uses wedge and peg connections.

487.30.text: And even the mallets to make it

489.44.text: can be provided on the cutting sheets as well.

491.92.text: And a team of about two or three people,

496.50.text: They don't need any traditional construction skills.

498.98.text: They don't need a huge array of power tools or anything like that,

502.13.text: and they can build a small house of about this size

516.71.text: And what you end up with is just the basic chassis of a house

519.70.text: onto which you can then apply systems like windows

522.16.text: and cladding and insulation and services

524.22.text: based on what's cheap and what's available.

527.27.text: Of course, the house is never finished.

529.45.text: We're shifting our heads here, so the house is not a finished product.

532.33.text: With the CNC machine, you can make new parts for it

535.09.text: over its life or even use it to make the house next door.

538.95.text: So we can begin to see the seed of a completely open-source,

546.66.text: And we and others have built a few prototypes around the world now,

550.21.text: and some really interesting lessons here.

552.33.text: One of them is that it's always incredibly sociable.

554.66.text: People get confused between construction work and having fun.

559.36.text: But the principles of openness go right down

562.02.text: into the really mundane, physical details.

564.82.text: Like, never designing a piece that can't be lifted up.

567.82.text: Or, when you're designing a piece,

569.12.text: make sure you either can't put it in the wrong way round,

572.00.text: or, if you do, it doesn't matter, because it's symmetrical.

574.96.text: Probably the principal which runs deepest with us

579.00.text: is the principal set out by Linus Torvalds,

584.68.text: which was that idea of, "Be lazy like a fox."

587.97.text: Don't reinvent the wheel every time.

589.68.text: Take what already works, and adapt it for your own needs.

593.47.text: Contrary to almost everything that you might get taught

596.05.text: at an architecture school, copying is good.

603.93.text: It's actually how we built buildings

605.54.text: for hundreds of years before the Industrial Revolution

608.04.text: in these sorts of community barn-raisings.

617.13.text: but it's a really, really big difference.
